import { z } from "zod";

export const SupportTicketSchema = z.object({
  $id: z.string(),
  $createdAt: z.string(),
  $updatedAt: z.string(),
  $permissions: z.array(z.string()),
  title: z.string().max(255, "Maximum length of 255 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  description: z.string().max(20000, "Maximum length of 20000 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  userId: z.string().max(36, "Maximum length of 36 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  teamId: z.string().max(36, "Maximum length of 36 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  category: z.enum(["general", "technical", "billing", "account", "api", "bug_report", "feature_request"]).default("null").nullish(),
  priority: z.enum(["low", "medium", "high", "urgent"]).default("null").nullish(),
  status: z.enum(["open", "in_progress", "waiting", "resolved", "closed"]).default("null").nullish(),
  messages: z.array(z.string().max(100000, "Maximum length of 100000 characters exceeded").default("null")).nullish(),
  deviceInfo: z.string().max(2000, "Maximum length of 2000 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  currentUrl: z.string().max(500, "Maximum length of 500 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  assignee: z.string().max(36, "Maximum length of 36 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  lastActivity: z.string().max(30, "Maximum length of 30 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
  attachments: z.array(z.string().max(36, "Maximum length of 36 characters exceeded").default("null")).nullish(),
  metadata: z.string().max(17000, "Maximum length of 17000 characters exceeded").default("null").nullish(),
});

export type SupportTicket = z.infer<typeof SupportTicketSchema>;

```

The problem is that the UI is using category values like:
- "account"
- "technical" 
- "feature"
- "bug"
- "integration"
- "general"
- "other"

But the database schema (from supportTicket.ts line 12) only accepts:
- "general"
- "technical"
- "billing"
- "account"
- "api"
- "bug_report"
- "feature_request"

The mismatches are:
1. "feature" should be "feature_request"
2. "bug" should be "bug_report"
3. "integration" is not in the allowed list
4. "other" is not in the allowed list

So when a user selects "Feature Request" (value="feature"), it tries to save "feature" but the database expects "feature_request".

The solution is to update the SupportInterface.vue select options to match the allowed enum values from the database schema.

```

1. **Change** `value="feature"` → `value="feature_request"`

content.text:
## ✅ Fixed!

The root cause has been resolved. The issue was a **mismatch between the UI dropdown values and the database schema**.

### What Was Wrong

The category dropdown in `SupportInterface.vue` was using incorrect values:
- ❌ `"feature"` instead of `"feature_request"`
- ❌ `"bug"` instead of `"bug_report"`
- ❌ `"integration"` (not in schema)
- ❌ `"other"` (not in schema)
- ❌ Missing `"billing"` and `"api"` options

### What Was Fixed

Updated the dropdown at `SupportInterface.vue:138-146` to use the exact enum values from the database schema:

```vue
<option value="general">General Question</option>
<option value="technical">Technical Issue</option>
<option value="billing">Billing</option>
<option value="account">Account Management</option>
<option value="api">API & Integration</option>
<option value="bug_report">Bug Report</option>
<option value="feature_request">Feature Request</option>
```

These now match the allowed values in the database schema: `["general", "technical", "billing", "account", "api", "bug_report", "feature_request"]`

### Result

Creating a support ticket will now succeed without the 400 error. All category values selected in the UI will be valid in the database.

I can see the issue! The Gemini CLI MCP is configured in your **project-specific** settings (`/Users/natedamstra/socialaize/.claude/settings.local.json`), but it's not available in the worktree because:

1. **Project-specific config** only applies to that specific project directory
2. **Worktrees** are separate directories and don't inherit the project settings
3. The Gemini MCP needs to be configured **globally** in `~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`

content.text:
## ✅ Setup Complete!

I've successfully configured the Gemini CLI MCP globally so it will work in all your projects, including worktrees. Here's what I did:

### Changes Made:

1. **Global MCP Configuration** (`~/Library/Application Support/Claude/claude_desktop_config.json`):
   - Added `gemini-cli` MCP server using `gemini-mcp-tool` package
   - Configured it with your `GEMINI_API_KEY`
   - This will now be available in **all projects**

2. **Worktree Permissions** (`.claude/settings.local.json`):
   - Added `mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini` to the allowed permissions list
   - This allows the worktree to use the Gemini MCP tool

### Configuration Details:

```json
{
  "gemini-cli": {
    "command": "npx",
    "args": ["-y", "gemini-mcp-tool"],
    "env": {
      "GEMINI_API_KEY": "AIzaSyAWNiGGAljfd2RlB7HHot1YkqcvY7T8B_4"
    }
  }
}
```

### Next Steps:

**You'll need to restart Claude Code** for the changes to take effect. After restarting:
- The Gemini MCP will be available in all your projects
- You can use the `mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini` tool in any worktree
- The tool will work just like it does in your main socialaize project

### Note on Worktrees:

Since worktrees are separate directories, they each have their own `.claude/settings.local.json` file. If you create new worktrees in the future and want to use Gemini there, you'll need to add the permission `mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini` to their settings file. Alternatively, you could create a shared settings template or script to set up new worktrees with the proper permissions.

### What This Means:

   - Main socialaize project
